content: What iconic structure, completed in 1889, was originally built as a temporary exhibit for the World's Fair and is now a symbol of Paris, France?

Ah, that's a great question! So, you're asking about an iconic structure that was originally built as a temporary exhibit for the World's Fair and is now a symbol of Paris, France. Completed in 1889, right? Let me think about this.

I know that the 1889 World's Fair, also known as the Exposition Universelle, was held in Paris to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the French Revolution. There were many impressive structures and inventions showcased at that fair.

Now, the most famous structure associated with Paris is the Eiffel Tower. It was indeed built for the 1889 World's Fair and designed by Gustave Eiffel. Initially, it was met with some criticism from the artistic community of Paris, who thought it was an eyesore. But over time, it has become a global cultural icon of France and one of the most recognizable structures in the world.

So, I believe the answer is the Eiffel Tower. It was built as a temporary exhibit for the 1889 World's Fair but was so popular and useful that it was never dismantled, as was originally planned. Instead, it has become a permanent part of the Paris skyline and a symbol of the city.
